I’ve written to Angela Rayner, the Secretary of State for Housing, Communities and Local Government, about billboards and digital adverts, asking her to do more to tackle the negative effect of outdoor advertising.
Elected Greens across the country have championed progressive new advertising policies, for example in places like Bristol, Sheffield and Edinburgh. When I was a local councillor in Bristol, I played a key role in securing the ban on advertising for junk food, alcohol, gambling and payday loans on council-owned billboards and advertising screens in Bristol.
It’s very promising to see councils implementing new policies to protect their residents from some of the impacts of consumerism, advertising, greenwashing and injustice. But that’s not enough. National planning laws need to change – they haven’t kept pace and it is clear that local authorities and communities need more power to object to harmful ads.
Chris Packham recently launched a petition asking for a national ban on fossil fuel advertising, it already has thousands of signatures. There is clear public support for more restrictions on advertising in public spaces and saying ‘no’ to greenwashing.

Tackling the Climate Emergency
Leading on urgent action to protect people and planet
Carla has consistently championed the rights of renters and worked to prevent homelessness in her roles as Green Party councillor, as the Green Party’s former Housing spokesperson, and as a member of the ACORN community union.
Believing in the right to warm, safe, affordable housing for all, she has continually advocated for measures such as rent controls and landlord licensing. Since 2016, Carla has urged the Mayor and Cabinet to expand landlord licensing across the city. In 2019 this call was heeded for a selection of wards near the city centre, and in 2023 the Council consulted on extending the scheme further. She has also supported the student rent strike during the covid pandemic, and committed to abolishing feudal leasehold forms of home ownership and replacing them with a system that offers people choice and control.
Carla has been vocal in her support and solidarity with the residents of Barton House, who were forced to evacuate their homes in Lawrence Hill in Bristol due to safety concerns. She joined growing calls for the council to pause the evacuated residents’ rent payments and called for an investigation into the handling of the incident.
This country needs public representatives with solutions that meet the challenge of the housing crisis. Carla is committed to measures which tackle the housing shortage while simultaneously protecting valuable green space for communities, reducing climate emissions, tackling fuel poverty and providing genuinely affordable homes.

An End to the Housing Crisis
Everyone in our city should have a safe, warm, affordable home
The world is waking up to the urgent need for climate action.
Carla pioneered the first Climate Emergency motion in Europe, setting a precedent by committing Bristol to achieve carbon neutrality by 2030. This bold initiative has since inspired governments, councils, and businesses across the continent to follow suit.
Since then Carla has continued advocating for climate action both in Bristol and nationally, saying no to any new oil and gas but yes to renewables, green jobs in a thriving green economy and retrofitting the UK’s cold and leaky housing.
The recent approval of the Rosebank oilfield shows we need Green MPs in Westminster more than ever. The Conservatives have given the go-ahead to Rosebank, the largest undrilled oilfield in the North Sea. Labour has said that they will not rescind the licence in Government. If Labour had the courage to say it would rescind the licence, it could render the investment unviable and the dangerous climate impact would be avoided. Neither political party is showing the climate leadership the world needs at this crucial moment in time.
We need people like Carla in Westminster to hold the government accountable to its environmental commitments and demand they treat the climate crisis with the urgency it requires.

Tackling the Climate Emergency
Leading on urgent action to protect people and planet
Everyone in Bristol wants our transport system to work better. Accessible, reliable and affordable public transport is the foundation of a thriving city – connecting people to each other, education, work, and crucial services, whilst tackling congestion, air pollution and climate change all at the same time.
Carla continues to lead the way on the campaign for fairer buses in Bristol through advocating for a franchising system similar to that in London and Manchester. This would give the local authority greater powers to set routes and frequencies rather than private companies cherry-picking the profitable routes while leaving other passengers out in the cold and some communities completely cut off. After years of campaigning by Carla, Bristol Green Party and a coalition of groups, the West of England Mayor has recently taken the first steps to considering bus franchising.
As your MP, Carla would continue to fight for a transport system that truly serves the needs of Bristol’s residents and the environment, not the profit of large companies.

My pledge to you
Bristol is a city of unique opportunities. We have the potential to be a beacon to the rest of the country and the world, demonstrating how collective action can overcome even the most daunting challenges.
Our city is talented, hard-working, imaginative, and kind – values that I will continue to embody as your MP. I remain dedicated to listening with an open mind and striving to help wherever I can. With my background as a renewable energy engineer, co-leader of the Green Party of England and Wales, and former Bristol City Councillor, I’ve dedicated my career to championing policies that will build a fairer, greener country.
As your MP, I will have the freedom to advocate for what is truly right for our city. I will not be swayed or coerced into supporting policies that do not benefit Bristol. My commitment is to listen to my constituents and vote with my conscience, ensuring your voices are heard in Parliament.
A Green vote in Bristol Central has proven to be more than just a vote against the Tories. It is a mandate to hold Labour accountable to their promises and to champion progressive, green policies. Together, we will continue to fight for a fairer, greener future. A vote for hope has now become a vote for action.
Thank you for your trust and support. Let’s build a brighter future for Bristol together.

Carla Denyer was elected as MP for Bristol Central in July 2024. Her background is in engineering and she was elected as co-leader of the Green Party of England and Wales in 2021.
I’ll be holding my next advice surgery on Saturday 10 May 2025.
I’m here to help on a range of issues such as housing, healthcare, welfare benefits and asylum and immigration. Please get in touch by emailing a brief summary of your case to bristolcentraloffice@parliament.uk
Limited slots available per session for Bristol Central constituents only.
Carla moved to Bristol after university to work as an engineer. In 2015 she was elected as a local councillor, a role she was in for 9 years. In July 2024 she was elected as MP for Bristol Central with the biggest Green vote share in the country (24,539 votes, 56.6%).
In 2018, she wrote and proposed the first Climate Emergency declaration in Europe, setting an ambitious goal for Bristol to become carbon neutral by 2030. This bold initiative has since been adopted by 570 UK councils, the UK Parliament, and the Scottish and Welsh governments.
As a councillor and campaigner, social justice is at the heart of Carla’s work. Whether on renters’ rights or access to public transport and key services, Carla had consistently stood up for the people who need it the most.
Before entering politics, Carla was an engineer in the renewable energy industry, specialising in offshore and onshore wind energy. Working in the sector, she saw that the solutions to create a greener, safer future are already available; what is lacking is the will of our political leaders. The good news is that this is something we can change by electing more Greens at every level of Government.
Carla Denyer is more than a politician; she is a dedicated advocate for the people of Bristol, for green policies, and for social justice.
